{
  "article_text": [
    "the study of magnetic fields generated by the turbulent motion of a charged conducting fluid is relevant for several astrophysical applications @xcite .",
    "an inhomogeneous flow of a charged fluid is able to locally produce a magnetic field .",
    "the advected field in turn generates electric currents in the fluid and these dissipate the magnetic energy because of the finite resistivity . depending on the properties of the flow , magnetic field creation or dissipation can prevail .",
    "+ to determine in general terms the presence or not of dynamo is a daunting task .",
    "however , as we will see , there are particular models which allow for a detailed treatment",
    ".    the evolution of an initially given magnetic field @xmath0 in an incompressible flow of a conducting fluid is determined by the following equations @xcite @xmath1 where @xmath2 is the velocity field .",
    "the magnetic diffusivity @xmath3 , which is assumed to be uniform and constant , is proportional to the inverse of the electric conductivity of the fluid .",
    "the term @xmath4 is a purely advective contribution that preserves the magnetic energy .",
    "the stretching term @xmath5 acts either as a energy source or as a sink depending on the local properties of the flow . finally , the diffusive term @xmath6 is responsible for the ohmic dissipation at small scales and balances with the inertial terms at the diffusive scale @xmath7 .",
    "+ the relative importance of the two contributions on the right - hand side of is given by the magnetic reynolds number @xmath8 , where @xmath9 denotes the integral scale of the flow and @xmath10 is the characteristic velocity at such scale .",
    "@xmath11 can be regarded as a dimensionless measure of the fluid conductivity . for @xmath12",
    "the diffusion dominates and the magnetic energy density ( proportional to @xmath13 ) always decays to zero in time . in the opposite limit , @xmath14 , the diffusion term is relevant only at very small scales and the magnetic field is almost frozen in the fluid .",
    "we can expect that at high magnetic reynolds numbers the flow is able to enhance the magnetic field , producing a consequent growth in time of @xmath13 . the last process is called dynamo effect , referring to the energy transfer from the velocity field to the magnetic one .",
    "+ the field @xmath15 acts on the velocity by means of the lorentz force , which yields a term proportional to @xmath16 in navier - stokes equations . in general",
    ", it would be necessary to take into account such feedback action on @xmath17 .",
    "however , since we are interested in understanding if the initial generation of the magnetic field is a persistent situation or not , we can assume for the initial conditions @xmath18 and neglect the lorentz force contribution . under this hypothesis",
    "the evolution equations are totally uncoupled from navier - stokes equations . following this kinematic approach ,",
    "we thus proceed as if @xmath19 was an assigned random field : given the initial condition @xmath0 and appropriate boundary conditions , eqs .",
    "completely determine the magnetic field evolution .",
    "for the prescribed velocity we refer to the kraichnan statistical ensemble @xcite , in which @xmath17 is assumed gaussian , homogeneous , isotropic and @xmath20-correlated in time .",
    "the reason for this choice is that analytical results can be obtained @xcite .",
    "a real turbulent flow is characterized by two scales : the integral scale @xmath9 and the viscous scale @xmath21 , at which the dissipation term and the transport one balance in navier - stokes equations . the velocity structure function is supposed to be smooth for @xmath22 , to scale as @xmath23 @xmath24 in the inertial range @xmath25 and to approach a constant value at scales much larger than @xmath9 . the parameter @xmath26 represents the hlder exponent of the structure function and can be thought of as a measure of the field roughness : for @xmath27 the velocity is smooth in space , while with @xmath28 we describe a diffusive field .",
    "it is well known that the magnetic dynamo can emerge for an helical flow due to the @xmath29-effect @xcite . here",
    "we will restrict to a parity invariant statistical ensemble , which does not give rise to @xmath29-effect .",
    "+ obviously , several generalizations of the model are possible . in ref .",
    "@xcite schekochihin _",
    "_ describe the case of a @xmath30-dimensional smooth velocity field with a generic degree of compressibility .",
    "the @xmath29-effect is taken into account in refs .",
    "@xcite respectively in the limit of large and small prandtl numbers .",
    "furthermore , the effect of the lorenz force is considered in refs .",
    "@xcite in the limiting case of very large prandtl numbers .",
    "the analysis of dynamo effect is made easier by a simple quantum mechanics formulation , first introduced by kazantsev @xcite .",
    "indeed , on account of the @xmath20-correlation in time of the kraichnan velocity field , the single time correlation function for the magnetic field @xmath31 can be expressed in terms of a function that satisfies a one - dimensional schrdinger - like equation .",
    "the problem of the dynamo effect can thus be mapped into that of studying the bound states of a quantum particle in a given potential that only depends on the velocity correlation function . in particular",
    ", the ground state energy @xmath32 of such potential will turn out to be the asymptotic magnetic field growth rate .",
    "the technique used to compute @xmath32 for different quantum potentials is the variation - iteration method described in appendix [ app : b ] .",
    "the aim of this paper is to single out the role that the velocity scales @xmath9 and @xmath21 play in dynamo theory . to this purpose",
    "it is interesting to study the magnetic field generation as the magnetic reynolds number @xmath11 and the prandtl number @xmath33 are varied ( @xmath34 denotes the viscosity of the fluid ) .",
    "indeed , they are related to the relative importance of the characteristic scales in the physical problem by the expressions @xmath35 and @xmath36 . + in ref .",
    "@xcite kazantsev finally restricts himself to the limiting case of @xmath37 and @xmath38 and proves that dynamo can take place only for a velocity scaling exponent in the range @xmath39 . here",
    "we show that in this range of @xmath26 the characteristic time of the dynamo effect is of order of the diffusive time @xmath40 and the magnetic field correlation length is of order @xmath7 .",
    "we also provide a numerical computation of the growth rate vs @xmath26 .",
    "+ then , we analyze the case of finite @xmath11 and prove that a critical magnetic reynolds number exists : if @xmath11 is sufficiently small , the dynamo does not ever take place , even for @xmath41 .",
    "+ finally , we show that the prandtl number does not affect the presence of dynamo , but only determines the magnetic field correlation length and the characteristic growth time .",
    "if @xmath42 , the field @xmath43 has a correlation length of order @xmath7 and it grows with a characteristic time scale of order @xmath44 . on the contrary , if @xmath45 , the correlation length is of order @xmath21 and the characteristic time of order @xmath46 , where @xmath46 represents the viscous time for the velocity field : @xmath47 .",
    "this paper is organized as follows .",
    "after this general introduction to the problem , in section [ k - k ] we define more precisely the kraichnan model and , following kazantsev @xcite , we describe the quantum formalism mentioned above .",
    "in particular we give the schrdinger equation that is the central point of this quantum approach . in section [ sec : t - d ] we revisit the case of infinite magnetic reynolds number and zero prandtl number .",
    "then , starting from these results , we analyse the effect of finite @xmath11 and we study how a nonzero @xmath48 influences the magnetic field evolution in time .",
    "in this section we recall in detail the quantum formalism introduced by kazantsev in ref .",
    "the random velocity field is assumed to be incompressible , gaussian , homogeneous , isotropic , parity invariant , and @xmath20-correlated in time . under these hypotheses",
    "it is completely defined by its correlation matrix @xmath49   \\qquad ( { \\bf r}={\\bf x}-{\\bf x ' } ) , \\end{split}\\ ] ] where @xmath50 denotes the structure function of the field @xmath51 .",
    "+ the @xmath20-correlation in time of @xmath51 is an essential property in order to write a closed equation for the magnetic field correlation function that , under a suitable transformation , reduces to a schrdinger - like equation .",
    "we impose homogeneous and isotropic initial conditions for @xmath43 .",
    "therefore , on account of the translational and rotational invariance of eqs . , the magnetic field maintains homogeneous and isotropic statistics at every time @xmath52 .",
    "its correlation tensor has thus the form ( see , e. g. , ref .",
    "@xcite ) @xmath53 because of the solenoidality condition @xmath54 , the functions @xmath55 and @xmath56 are related by the following differential equation @xmath57 the covariance of @xmath43 is then completely described by a single scalar function , e. g. , its trace @xmath58 .",
    "the dynamo effect will correspond to an unbounded growth in time of @xmath59 .",
    "+ the correlation function @xmath59 can be transformed into another function @xmath60 that solves the imaginary time schrdinger equation @xmath61\\psi=0\\ ] ] in which the mass and the potential depend on @xmath62 only through @xmath63 .",
    "( for the details see the appendix [ app : a ] and ref .",
    "@xcite ) . + to study the dynamo effect it is useful to put in evidence the time dependence of @xmath64 . as usual in quantum mechanics , we thus expand the ` wave function ' @xmath64 in terms of the ` energy ' eigenfunctions @xmath65 ( or @xmath66 for discrete energy levels ) and get the ` stationary ' equation @xmath67\\psi_e=0.\\ ] ] referring to the meaning of @xmath64 , it is clear that an unbounded growth of the magnetic field corresponds to the existence of negative energies in eq . .",
    "in particular , it is the sign of the ground state energy @xmath32 that determines the presence of dynamo and its value eventually represents the asymptotic growth rate of the magnetic field .",
    "indeed , in this case it is the ground state @xmath68 that dominates the growth in time .",
    "( recall that the negative energy levels of a schrdinger equation are always discrete ) .    by looking at the variational expression for the eigenvalues in @xmath69 one",
    "can easily conclude that the presence of dynamo effect is equivalent to the existence of bound states for a quantum particle of unit ( @xmath62-independent ) mass in the potential @xmath70 @xcite .",
    "therefore , in order to state if dynamo can take place for a given velocity field , it is sufficient to study the properties of @xmath71 .",
    "having summarized the quantum mechanics formalism for a magnetic field transported by a kraichnan turbulent flow , in the next section we study the dynamo effect for a velocity correlation function that mimics the real physical situation .",
    "in particular , we numerically compute @xmath32 and describe the properties of the ground state eigenfunction as @xmath11 and @xmath48 are varied . from this analysis",
    "we are able to obtain information about the critical magnetic reynolds number , the correlation length of the magnetic field , the asymptotic behaviours of its correlation function , and the characteristic time - scale of the magnetic field growth .",
    "we consider the realistic situation of a structure function @xmath63 that scales as @xmath72 for @xmath22 , as expected in the viscous range , as @xmath23 @xmath73 in the inertial range @xmath25 , and tends to a constant value @xmath74 for @xmath75 .",
    "+ the case @xmath28 corresponds to the diffusive behaviour , while the other limit @xmath27 describes a velocity field that is smooth at all scales below the correlation length @xmath9 .",
    "for the other values of @xmath26 , in the inertial range @xmath63 is only an hlder continuous function of @xmath62 with exponent @xmath76 . the parameter @xmath26 thus represents a measure of the field roughness .",
    "an explicit expression for the velocity correlation tensor , which has the desired scaling properties , is , for example , @xmath77 the solenoidal projector @xmath78 ensures the incompressibility of the velocity field .",
    "+ in what follows we refer to eq . whenever we show numerical computations that exemplify our conclusions .",
    "however , it should be noted that our results are general : they depend only on the qualitative properties of @xmath63 and not on its explicit form .",
    "we first consider the limiting case of @xmath14 and @xmath79 . under these conditions",
    "the diffusive scale @xmath7 is in the inertial range and the presence of the cutoffs @xmath9 and @xmath21 is neglected : only the scaling behaviour @xmath23 @xmath80 is considered for the velocity structure function .",
    "+ the general expression of @xmath81 for an homogeneous , isotropic , parity invariant , incompressible field that scales as @xmath23 is @xcite @xmath82\\ ] ] where the coefficient @xmath83 has the dimensions of @xmath84 .",
    "+ in this limit the total energy @xmath74 diverges with the infrared cutoff as @xmath85 .    in order to analyze the existence of the dynamo ,",
    "let us turn to the quantum formulation described above .",
    "the potential @xmath71 has the following asymptotic behaviours ( see the appendix [ app : a ] and ref .",
    "@xcite for the complete expression ) @xmath86 for sufficiently small @xmath26 the potential is positive for all @xmath62 , it does not generate bound states and therefore the dynamo can not take place . for larger @xmath26 , @xmath71 is repulsive up to @xmath87 and becomes attractive at infinity ( fig .",
    "[ fig:1 ] ) . a quantum mechanical analysis based on asymptotic behaviours allows to establish that @xmath88 is the exact threshold for the dynamo effect @xcite .",
    "if @xmath89 the turbulent flow alone is unable to increase the magnetic field and @xmath13 decays in time . for those values of @xmath26 , the presence of a forcing term in eq . is necessary to obtain a statistically stationary state .",
    "see vergassola @xcite for the detailed analysis .",
    "from now on we restrict to the values @xmath90 , for which the dynamo is present .",
    "is rewritten in a rescaled form by means of the transformation @xmath91 , @xmath92 , it is easy to see that the eigenvalues of the energy must take the form @xmath93 where @xmath94 depends only on the scaling exponent @xmath26 and @xmath44 is the characteristic time of magnetic diffusion .",
    "+ we have already noted that the ground state eigenfunction dominates the evolution in time and that @xmath32 is the asymptotic magnetic growth rate .",
    "we numerically compute @xmath95 as a function of @xmath26 by the variation - iteration method described in the appendix [ app : b ] .",
    "the quantity @xmath96 grows with @xmath26 as shown in fig .",
    "[ fig:2 ] .",
    "when @xmath26 tends to one , @xmath96 approaches zero and the bound states disappear . in the other limit",
    ", @xmath96 reaches the value @xmath97 according to the results of kazantsev @xcite .",
    "an estimation for @xmath96 vs @xmath26 already appears in ref .",
    "@xcite , but there the results are limited to the values @xmath98 . moreover ,",
    "the numerical computations in that paper are performed by a variational method based on the particular guess @xmath99 for the eigenfunction @xmath100 .",
    "this ansatz is correct for @xmath101 , but it fails to capture the right behaviour for @xmath102 . indeed ,",
    "if we insert the asymptotic behaviours in eq . , we find that , for @xmath103 , @xmath104 shows for @xmath102 a stretched exponential decay with characteristic scale @xmath7 and stretching exponent @xmath105 ( fig .",
    "[ fig:3 ] ) .",
    "the variation - iteration method we used ( see the appendix [ app : b ] ) presents the big advantage of not requiring an explicit form for @xmath100 .",
    "the algorithm provides as results both the eigenvalue and the corresponding eigenfunction .    from the expressions of @xmath106 we can recover the behaviour of @xmath59 ( see the definition in appendix [ app : a ] ) .",
    "we have that , for @xmath101 , @xmath59 is approximately constant , while , if @xmath103 , the magnetic field correlation function decays for @xmath102 as a stretched exponential with scale @xmath7 @xmath107 % \\qquad ( r_d\\ll r\\ll l ) .",
    "h(r , t)\\propto e^{-\\beta\\,\\left ( r / r_d\\right)^{(2-\\xi)/2 } } \\qquad ( r_d\\ll r\\ll l).\\ ] ] the prefactor @xmath108 depends on the growth rate @xmath95 .",
    "we can thus conclude that , for @xmath103 , the magnetic field has a spatial distribution characterized by structures whose scales are of order @xmath7 .",
    "+ the cases @xmath27 and @xmath88 have to be treated separately .",
    "indeed , the asymptotic properties can not be deduced directly from eq . .",
    "+ the smooth case is solved by chertkov _",
    "@xcite by a lagrangian approach that relates the growth rate to the lyapunov exponents .",
    "there is a big difference between the situation of a smooth velocity field and one that is just hlder continuous . in the former case the correlation function",
    "is found to depend on the spatial coordinate as @xmath109 ( equivalent to @xmath110 ) , which implies the presence of structures with at least one dimension of inertial range size .",
    "actually the magnetic field in the smooth case has been shown to be characterized by strip - like objects .",
    "+ finally , the case @xmath88 can be solved exactly .",
    "indeed , the appropriate ground state eigenfunction of eq .",
    "is ( recall that @xmath88 is the threshold for dynamo and hence @xmath111 ) @xmath112 where the constant @xmath113 is related to the value of @xmath114 by the relation @xmath115 .",
    "+ if we neglect logarithmic corrections , the asymptotic behaviour of @xmath116 for @xmath102 is @xmath117 , which yields again @xmath118 for @xmath102 .",
    "the results we have outlined in this section will be useful in the following to describe the general case where the velocity energy spectrum has an infrared and an ultraviolet cutoff .",
    "indeed , we will study a structure function that for @xmath119 scales as @xmath72 and so takes the @xmath27 behaviour , while for @xmath75 tends to a constant value like in the diffusive case @xmath28 .",
    "let us analyze the situation of finite @xmath11 ( and zero prandtl number ) .",
    "the principal fact is that a large scale cutoff @xmath9 appears for velocity field correlations .",
    "the diffusive scale @xmath7 is again within the inertial range of the velocity fluctuations , and the presence of the viscous cutoff can be neglected .",
    "the velocity structure function therefore scales as @xmath23 for @xmath120 and tends to @xmath74 for @xmath75 .",
    "+ therefore , the potential @xmath71 behaves as in the previous case for @xmath120 , while it takes the @xmath28 behaviour for @xmath75 @xmath121 the main consequence of a finite @xmath11 is that @xmath71 is repulsive also at large scales .",
    "it is thus clear that , for sufficiently high @xmath11 , a potential well is present at scales of order @xmath7 . on the contrary ,",
    "if @xmath11 is too small , the well can be absent or anyway not deep enough to generate bound states ( see fig .",
    "[ fig:4 ] ) .",
    "therefore , we can conclude that for sufficiently small @xmath11 , the dynamo does not take place , even for @xmath103 .",
    "+ the effect of a large scale cutoff on the velocity energy spectrum is thus the presence of a critical reynolds number @xmath122 . for @xmath11 smaller than that value",
    "the potential @xmath71 has not bound states or equivalently , on account of our quantum mechanic interpretation , the velocity field is unable to favour the magnetic field growth and",
    "the ohmic dissipation eventually prevails on stretching .",
    "+ the dependence of the dimensionless rate - of - growth @xmath123 on @xmath11 is shown in fig .",
    "[ fig:5 ] for @xmath124 in the case of the scaling @xmath125 .",
    "notice that , for @xmath126 , @xmath32 takes the inertial range behaviour @xmath127 .",
    "we can again deduce from eq .",
    "some properties of the function @xmath59 .",
    "the correlation length of the magnetic field is again of order @xmath7 and , at @xmath75 , @xmath59 shows an exponential decay @xmath128 with @xmath129^{-1}$ ] , @xmath130 .",
    "finally , we consider the situation of nonzero prandl number ( at infinite reynolds number ) .",
    "this is equivalent to look at the effect of the viscous scale on the dynamo effect .",
    "+ if @xmath131 , the diffusive scale @xmath7 is in the inertial range , while , if @xmath45 , it lies within the viscous range .",
    "the structure function @xmath63 scales as @xmath72 for @xmath119 and as @xmath23 for @xmath132 .",
    "+ from the previous considerations we can expect for the potential @xmath71 the same asymptotic behaviours for @xmath133 as in the case of @xmath134 .",
    "therefore , the prandtl number does not influence the presence of dynamo .",
    "what is sensitive to @xmath48 is the correlation length of the magnetic field , that approximately corresponds to the scale at which the function @xmath100 begin its exponential - like decay .",
    "when @xmath42 , the potential has nearly the same shape as in the case @xmath134 @xmath135 and the correlation length is of order @xmath7 .",
    "+ on the contrary , when @xmath45 , the potential well is modified by an attractive @xmath27 contribution @xmath136 for these @xmath48 the function @xmath106 grows as @xmath72 for @xmath101 , as @xmath137 in the range @xmath138 and has a stretched exponential decay for @xmath139 .",
    "we can thus conclude that , when @xmath45 , the magnetic field correlation length is of order @xmath21 .    on account of what we have just seen",
    ", we expect that for @xmath140 the ground state energy will be proportional to the diffusive time : @xmath141 . in the other limit , @xmath142",
    ", we can predict an approximate expression for @xmath32 by a simple scaling argument . indeed , for large @xmath48 the potential @xmath71 behaves like in the case @xmath27 and we can expect @xmath143 ( see ref .",
    "@xcite for the discussion of the smooth case ) . knowing that @xmath144 for @xmath22 and @xmath145 in the inertial range",
    ", we can match the previous behaviours to obtain @xmath146 .",
    "finally , we recall that from dimensional arguments we have @xmath147 . summarizing the previous considerations , it is easily seen that , for @xmath142 , the relation @xmath148 holds ( the time @xmath46 is the characteristic one for the velocity diffusion ) .",
    "+ the prandtl number @xmath149 thus influences also the magnetic field rate - of - growth : in presence of dynamo , @xmath13 increases with a characteristic time - scale determined by the largest beetween the viscous and the diffusive time ( see fig .",
    "[ fig:6 ] ) .    to conclude this section",
    ", we discuss a result that emerges from numerical computations : for @xmath150 the magnetic growth rate reaches a maximum ( fig .",
    "[ fig:6 ] ) .",
    "we can easily guess this behaviour , if we refer once more to the kazantsev quantum formalism .",
    "for @xmath42 the @xmath27 behaviour is practically absent in the potential @xmath71 , while , when @xmath48 approaches the value @xmath151 , the scale @xmath21 begins to come into play yielding a strongly attractive @xmath152 contribution at scales @xmath153 .",
    "the @xmath27 potential is more attractive than that of other @xmath26 and the ground state energy increases in absolute value .",
    "then , as @xmath48 becomes larger , @xmath154 decreases as explained above .",
    "in other words as long as the viscous behaviour affects only the potential shape around @xmath7 , its only effect is to make the well deeper and so to favour the dynamo .",
    "when viscousity becomes very large , the level of velocity fluctuations lowers significantly , inducing eventually the depletion of the rate - of - growth .",
    "the presence of dynamo effect for a magnetic field advected by a conducting fluid is strongly dependent on the properties of the turbulent flow .",
    "we have highlighted in the framework of the kraichnan ensemble the consequences of considering a viscous and an integral cutoff for the velocity . using the quantum formalism introduced by kazantsev",
    ", we have found that a critical magnetic reynolds number exists . by the same method",
    ", we have shown that the prandtl number is the parameter that determines the correlation length of the magnetic field and the characteristic time of its growth .",
    "finally , we have argued that in the presence of dynamo the magnetic growth rate is maximum fo prandtl number of order unity . as already noted , the previous analysis depends only on the qualitative properties of the velocity structure function , so we expect our conclusions to hold for a generic turbulent flow with same statistical simmetries and therefore to be relevant for real applications .",
    "i would like to express my gratitude to a. celani for his fundamental contribution in developing this work .",
    "a. mazzino and m. vergassola are also acknowledged for useful discussions and suggestions .",
    "this work was supported by the doctoral grants of the nice university , by the department of physics of the genova university , and by the european union under contract hprn - ct-2000 - 00162 .",
    "for the numerical analysis of schrdinger equation we make the transformation @xmath155 @xmath156 which maps @xmath157 on the finite interval @xmath158 .",
    "( the constant @xmath159 should be chosen to properly resolve this interval ) .",
    "eq . can thus be rewritten in the form @xmath160 { \\mathcal m}=\\dfrac{m(y)}{y}\\qquad\\qquad \\lambda = e - u_{min}\\end{array}\\end{gathered}\\ ] ] and @xmath161 denotes the minimum value of @xmath10 . @xmath162 and @xmath163 are positive - definite self - adjoint operators defining a spectrum of eigenvalues @xmath164 bounded from below and which extends to infinity .",
    "moreover , @xmath162 is invertible on all functions twice differentiable on @xmath158 and vanishing at the boundaries of the interval . under these hypotheses",
    "the variation - iteration method described in ref .",
    "@xcite provides a valuable tool to compute the lowest eigenvalue @xmath165 of eq . and the corresponding eigenfunction @xmath116 .",
    "indeed , let @xmath166 be an initial trial function such that @xmath167 and define the @xmath168th iterate @xmath169 as @xmath170 then , as @xmath168 is increased , the sequence @xmath169 converges to the eigenfunction @xmath166 . the @xmath168th approximation to @xmath165",
    "is given by the following variational expression employing @xmath169 as trial function @xmath171 the set @xmath172 form a monotonic sequence of decreasing values , approaching @xmath165 from the above .",
    "the advantage of the variation - iteration technique is that no expression is required _ a priori _ for the function @xmath116 .",
    "we only have to choose any guess for initial function @xmath166 and then improve the result by iterating the method for sufficiently large @xmath168 .",
    "the convergence is more rapid the smaller is the ratio between @xmath165 and the following eigenvalue .    finally , for the numerical implementation of the method , we exploited the first order discrete expression of @xmath162 preserving the boundary conditions on @xmath173 .",
    "if @xmath158 is divided in intervals of length @xmath174 and @xmath175 , we have @xmath176",
    "in the present appendix we refer to the notation adopted in the body of the paper .",
    "so , the trace of the correlation tensor @xmath177 will be denoted by @xmath59 . + as a consequence of the velocity @xmath20-correlation in time , @xmath178 satisfies a closed equation that , under a suitable transformation , takes on the form of a one - dimensional schrdinger - like equation . in order to exploit this fact , let us denote @xmath179 and define the following quantities @xmath180 then , the function @xmath181 solves the imaginary time schrdinger equation @xmath182\\psi=0\\ ] ] where @xmath183 ( see ref .",
    "@xcite for the detailed derivation ) .",
    "if we expand @xmath64 in terms of the energy eigenfunctions @xmath65 , we get the stationary equation @xmath184\\psi_e=0.\\ ] ] the dynamo effect corresponds to the presence of negative eigenvalues in eq . .",
    "+ the correlation function @xmath185 must tends to a constant value as @xmath186 and decreases to zero as @xmath133 . from the definition we have therefore that eq .",
    "must be solved with the boundary conditions that @xmath104 vanishes as @xmath186 and increases as @xmath133 slowly enough to guarantee that @xmath185 decreases to zero .",
    "in particular , if @xmath187 tends to a constant as @xmath133 , @xmath104 can not increase more rapidly than @xmath62 .      in the limits",
    "@xmath190 and @xmath191 , @xmath81 takes the form @xmath192\\\\ \\intertext{with } d_1=\\dfrac{4\\pi\\cos\\left(\\frac{\\pi\\xi}{2}\\right ) \\gamma(-1-\\xi)}{\\xi+3}d_0.\\end{gathered}\\ ] ] ( the function @xmath193 is the euler function ) .",

    "the numerical computation is performed using expression for the correlation tensor of the magnetic field .",
    "+   + fig . 6 : the dependence of the magnetic growth rate on the prandtl number for @xmath125 and in the limit @xmath37 .",
    "the numerical computation is performed using expression for the correlation tensor of the magnetic field ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> the problem of the dynamo effect for a kraichnan incompressible helicity - free velocity field is considered . exploiting a quantum formalism first introduced by kazantsev ( a.p .  </S>",
    "<S> kazantsev , sov . </S>",
    "<S> phys . </S>",
    "<S> jetp * 26 * , 1031 - 1034 ( 1968 ) ) , we show that a critical magnetic reynolds number exists for the presence of dynamo . </S>",
    "<S> the value of the prandtl number influences the spatial distribution of the magnetic field and its growth in time . </S>",
    "<S> the magnetic field correlation length is always the largest between the diffusive scale and the viscous scale of the flow . in the same way the field growth is characterized by a time scale that corresponds to the largest between the diffusive and the viscous characteristic time . </S>",
    "<S> +   + * keywords * : turbulent transport , magnetohydrodynamics , dynamo effect , kraichnan statistical ensemble    suggested running head : the kraichnan - kazantsev dynamo +    11em 1em -0.1em 0.5pt plus 0.25pt minus 0.25pt    dario vincenzi + cnrs umr 6529 + bd . de lobservatoire + bp 4229 + 06304 nice cedex 4 - france    + 33 - 4 - 92003172    + 33 - 4 - 92003121    vincenzi@obs-nice.fr </S>"
  ]
}
